cosmology.name: The Great Wheel
cosmology.description: The default D&D cosmology includes more than two dozen planes. The most common understanding visualizes them as a group of concentric wheels, with the material realms at the center. The Inner Planes form a wheel around the Material Plane, enveloped in the Ethereal Plane. Then the Outer Planes form another wheel around that one, arranged according to alignment, with the Outlands linking them all.

alternateConfigurations.name: World Tree
alternateConfigurations.description: Planes situated among the roots and branches of a great cosmic tree (literally or figuratively).

alternateConfigurations.name: Astral Dominant
alternateConfigurations.description: Material realms suspended between two other realities: the astral realms (the Astral Plane and the Outer Planes) above and the elemental realms (the Inner Planes) below.

alternateConfigurations.name: Simplified Cosmology
alternateConfigurations.description: A cosmology with fewer planes: a Material Plane; the Transitive Planes; a single undifferentiated Elemental Plane, where all four elements churn in chaos; an Overheaven, where good deities and Celestials dwell; and an Underworld, where evil deities and Fiends reside.

alternateConfigurations.name: Orbital Cosmology
alternateConfigurations.description: Planes arranged in a complex system of orbits, with planes exerting greater influence on the Material Plane the closer they draw to it.

planeCategories.name: Material Realms
planeCategories.description: Most D&D worlds are located on the Material Plane, which has two planar echoes: the Feywild and the Shadowfell.

planeCategories.name: Transitive Planes
planeCategories.description: The Ethereal Plane and the Astral Plane are boundless realms that provide passage between other planes of existence.

planeCategories.name: Inner Planes
planeCategories.description: The four Elemental Planes (Air, Earth, Fire, and Water), plus the Para-elemental Planes between them, are the Inner Planes.

planeCategories.name: Outer Planes
planeCategories.description: Seventeen Outer Planes correspond to the nine alignments and shades of philosophical difference between them.

planeCategories.name: Positive and Negative Planes
planeCategories.description: These two planes enfold the rest of the cosmology, providing the raw forces of life and death that underlie all existence in the multiverse.

planes.name: Material Plane
planes.philosophicalEssence: The Material Plane is where the philosophical and elemental forces of the other planes of existence collide in the jumbled existence of mortal life and matter. It is a thoroughly magical place, reflected in the two planes that share its central place in the multiverse.
planes.emotionalInfluence: None inherent; serves as the baseline for all other planar effects.

physicalProperties.shape: The Material Plane contains infinitely diverse worlds, each situated within a Wildspace system. Worlds vary in form and geography.
physicalProperties.atmosphereNotes: Standard breathable atmosphere on habitable worlds; Wildspace between worlds is airless.

temperature.description: Temperature varies by world, region, and climate. The Material Plane serves as the baseline for normal environmental conditions.

physicalProperties.dominantElement: All four elements mingle together on the Material Plane, forming land, sea, and sky.
physicalProperties.weatherPatterns: Normal weather patterns vary by world and region.

timeFlow.description: Time flows normally on the Material Plane. It serves as the baseline by which time flow on all other planes is measured.

portals.name: Fey Crossings

requirement.description: Fey crossings are places of mystery and beauty on the Material Plane that have a near-perfect mirror in the Feywild. A traveler passes through by entering a clearing, wading into a pool, passing into a circle of mushrooms, or crawling under the trunk of a tree. Most open infrequently, such as during a full moon, on the dawn of a particular day, or for someone carrying a certain type of item. A fey crossing can be closed permanently if the land on either side is dramatically altered.
requirement.situationCondition: Varies; may require full moon, specific day, specific item, or other conditions

portals.colorOrAppearance: Natural feature such as a clearing, pool, circle of mushrooms, or tree trunk

portals.name: Shadow Crossings

requirement.description: Shadow crossings form in gloomy places where spirits or the stench of death lingers, such as battlefields, graveyards, and tombs. They manifest only in darkness, closing as soon as they feel light's kiss.
requirement.situationCondition: Must be in darkness; closes when exposed to light

portals.colorOrAppearance: A blot of shadow in a dark place, such as the corner of a dusty crypt or an open grave

portals.name: Elemental Vortices

requirement.description: Vortices join an Elemental Plane with a very similar location on the Material Plane, such as a swirling pool of magma in the heart of a volcano (leading to the Plane of Fire) or a maelstrom in the depths of the ocean (leading to the Plane of Water).
requirement.situationCondition: Located at sites of extreme elemental activity

portals.colorOrAppearance: Appears as an intense natural elemental phenomenon such as volcanic magma or ocean maelstrom

portals.name: Nexus Points
portals.destination: Corresponding location on another Material Plane world

requirement.description: Nexus points are locations that exist in multiple worlds at the same time, possibly located at or near the roots of the worlds where seedlings of the First World's great tree took root. Shifting worlds might require the use of magic, an object from the desired destination world as a sort of key, or nothing more than an act of will. Some nexus points flit from world to world on a regular schedule.
requirement.situationCondition: Varies by nexus point; may require magic, a key object from destination world, or an act of will

portals.colorOrAppearance: Can be a geographical feature (enormous tree, mountain, mesa, cavern, meteorite crater) or a constructed feature (tower, castle, tavern, city)

planarConnections.name: Wildspace
planarConnections.description: Wildspace systems are vast, airless expanses in the Astral Plane where the Astral Plane overlaps with the Material Plane. Every world of the Material Plane is situated in a Wildspace system. Creatures and objects in Wildspace age normally and exist on both the Astral Plane and Material Plane simultaneously, enabling use of spells such as Teleport to travel from Wildspace to a nearby world or vice versa.

planarConnections.name: Yggdrasil, the World Tree
planarConnections.description: The World Tree, Yggdrasil, is a cosmic ash tree that spans the Outer Planes and links them to many worlds of the Material Plane. Its branches stretch through the Upper Planes and across the Astral to the Material Plane. Planar travelers can climb among the roots and branches to travel from plane to plane or world to world.
hazards: Ever-changing paths as the tree continues eternal growth

notableEntities.name: Corellon
notableEntities.title: God who planted and tended a great tree on the First World
notableEntities.description: A god who planted a seedling of Yggdrasil on the First World at the dawn of time. When the First World was destroyed, seeds from this tree scattered into the void and took root to form the worlds of the Material Plane.

specialRules.name: First World Origin
specialRules.description: Some legends speak of a primordial state, a single reality called the First World, where many of the peoples and monsters that inhabit the worlds on the Material Plane originated. After the First World was shattered by a great cataclysm, the many worlds were formed like reflections or (in some cases) distortions of that original reality.
specialRules.mechanicalEffect: No direct mechanical effect. Provides cosmological context for the existence of multiple Material Plane worlds and their shared creatures and peoples.

specialRules.name: Traveling Between Worlds
specialRules.description: Transit between the worlds of the Material Plane is rare but not impossible. Four methods exist: The Dream of Other Worlds (magic-aided deep slumber), The Great Journey (epic voyage through Wildspace/Astral Plane, Shadowfell, or Feywild), The Leap to Another Realm (spells such as Teleportation Circle or Teleport, or magical portals), and The Roots of the Worlds (nexus points that exist in multiple worlds simultaneously).
specialRules.mechanicalEffect: Characters can travel between Material Plane worlds via Wildspace and the Astral Plane aboard magic-powered vessels, through the Shadowfell or Feywild along less charted routes, via spells such as Teleportation Circle or Teleport targeting known circles or locations in other worlds, or through nexus points which may require magic, a key object from the destination world, or an act of will. Some nexus points shift between worlds on a regular schedule, lingering on one world for anywhere from a year to an hour before carrying everyone inside to a new world.

modifiedSpells.modification: Can be used to travel to a known teleportation circle on another Material Plane world.
Can be used to travel to a known location on another Material Plane world.

crossReferences.description: Contains extensive information about Wildspace and Astral travel between Material Plane worlds.
The D&D Settings table lists the most widely known worlds of the Material Plane that have been published as official campaign settings.

globalPlanarConnections.name: Infinite Staircase
globalPlanarConnections.description: The Infinite Staircase is an extradimensional staircase that connects the planes. An entrance usually appears as a nondescript door. Beyond the portal lies a small landing with a stairway leading up and down. Doors to the Infinite Staircase are often tucked away in dusty, half-forgotten places.
hazards: Guarded by devas, sphinxes, yugoloths, and other powerful monsters
navigableBy: Any creature that can find a door

globalPlanarConnections.name: River Oceanus
globalPlanarConnections.description: The water of the Oceanus is sweet and fragrant, originating in Elysium. It flows through each of Elysium's layers, passes through the top layer of the Beastlands, streams across the top layer of Arborea, and finally drains away somewhere in Arborea's second layer.

globalPlanarConnections.name: River Styx
globalPlanarConnections.description: The River Styx bubbles with grease, foul flotsam, and the putrid remains of battles along its banks. It churns through the top layers of Acheron, the Nine Hells, Gehenna, Hades, Carceri, the Abyss, and Pandemonium. Tributaries snake through lower layers of these planes.
hazards: Ill effects of the Styx (see chapter 3)
navigableBy: Sinister ferries crewed by Fiends or souls of dead mortals

globalPlanarConnections.name: Yggdrasil, the World Tree
globalPlanarConnections.description: The World Tree, Yggdrasil, is a cosmic ash tree that spans the Outer Planes and links them to many worlds of the Material Plane. Its roots stretch into the Lower Planes, touching Hades, Pandemonium, and possibly other Lower Planes. Most of its massive trunk rises through Ysgard, and its branches stretch through the Upper Planes and across the Astral to the Material Plane.

bloodWar.description: Throughout history, the teeming demon hordes of the Abyss and the regimented legions of devils from the Nine Hells have battled for supremacy in the cosmos. The Blood War is a conflict that has raged for millennia, ravaging the Lower Planes. A moment never goes by when demons and devils aren't battling each other somewhere in the multiverse.

factions.name: Demon Hordes
factions.role: Teeming chaotic hordes seeking to overwhelm through numbers and fury

factions.name: Devil Legions
factions.role: Regimented legions seeking supremacy through order and strategy

bloodWar.adventureImplications: Many demons and devils are obsessed with finding some advantage for their side in the Blood War, and powerful mortal adventurers are sometimes drawn into tangled schemes to that end. Open conflict between Fiends is a constant threat on most of the Lower Planes. Natives of the Upper Planes take steps to minimize the threat to the rest of the multiverse whenever the Blood War spills outside the Abyss and the Nine Hells.

planarTravelMethods.name: Planar Portals
planarTravelMethods.description: A portal is a stationary, interplanar connection that links a specific location on one plane to a specific location on another. Some function like doorways, others are locations that exist on multiple planes at once, and some are vortices joining elemental planes to similar Material Plane locations. Portals can require a command word, key item, random timing, situational condition, or time-based trigger to function.
requirements: Meeting the portal's activation requirements (command, key item, random, situation, or time)
risks: Guardians charged with ensuring certain creatures don't pass through
Portal may not be open when needed
destinations: Any plane, depending on the specific portal

planarTravelMethods.name: Planar Travel Spells
planarTravelMethods.description: A number of spells allow direct or indirect access to different planes of existence. Gate and Plane Shift can directly transport adventurers to any other plane, with different degrees of precision. Etherealness allows adventurers to enter the Ethereal Plane. Astral Projection lets adventurers project themselves into the Astral Plane and from there travel to the Outer Planes.
requirements: Ability to cast the relevant spell
risks: Varying degrees of precision in destination
destinations: Any plane, depending on the spell

planarTravelMethods.name: The Dream of Other Worlds
planarTravelMethods.description: Aided by magic, travelers can fall into a deep slumber and dream themselves into a new realm on another world of the Material Plane.
requirements: Magic to aid the deep slumber
destinations: Other worlds of the Material Plane

planarTravelMethods.name: The Great Journey
planarTravelMethods.description: Characters can undertake an epic voyage fraught with peril and obstacles. One route leads through Wildspace and across the Astral Plane aboard a vessel powered by magic. It is also possible to travel through the Shadowfell or the Feywild, though such routes are less charted and no less perilous.
requirements: A magic-powered vessel for Wildspace travel
Access to the Shadowfell or Feywild for alternative routes
risks: Less charted routes through Shadowfell or Feywild
destinations: Other worlds of the Material Plane

planarTravelMethods.name: The Leap to Another Realm
planarTravelMethods.description: The most direct method of traveling between Material Plane worlds involves the use of spells such as Teleportation Circle or Teleport, or magical portals. This magic causes the user to appear in a known teleportation circle or some other location in another world.
requirements: Knowledge of destination teleportation circle or location
Ability to cast Teleportation Circle, Teleport, or access to a suitable portal
destinations: Other worlds of the Material Plane

planarTravelMethods.name: The Roots of the Worlds
planarTravelMethods.description: Nexus points are locations that exist in multiple worlds at the same time, possibly located at or near the roots of the worlds where the seedlings of the First World's great tree took root. A nexus point can be a geographical feature or a constructed feature. Shifting worlds might require the use of magic, an object from the desired destination world as a sort of key, or nothing more than an act of will. Some nexus points flit from world to world on a regular schedule, lingering for anywhere from a year to an hour.
requirements: May require magic, a key object from destination world, or an act of will
risks: Some nexus points shift between worlds on a schedule, potentially stranding travelers
destinations: Other worlds of the Material Plane

infernalHierarchy.title: Duke/duchess
canDemoteTo: Any lesser or greater devil form

infernalHierarchy.title: Archduke/archduchess
canDemoteTo: Any lesser or greater devil form

planarAdventureSituations.situation: When magic fails to revive a dead person, the only solution is to venture to the Outer Planes to find the person's spirit and either release it from some prison or convince the person to return to life.

People who venture into the woods keep accidentally wandering into the Feywild or the Shadowfell. They might never return, return with no sense of how much time has passed, or return dramatically changed.
A long-dead oracle is the only one who knows how a terrible prophecy might be averted, but the cataclysmic fulfillment of the prophecy has already begun.
A god has stopped answering prayers and won't respond to any Commune spell.
A devil has tricked an angel into meddling in the Blood War, and the angel seeks mortal aid.
An ancestor of one of the characters must be convinced to bless the character before the full power of the character's bloodline can be unleashed.
A foolhardy knight carried a holy weapon on a doomed mission into the Nine Hells, and the powers of Mount Celestia want the weapon and the knight's remains retrieved.
A titan is imprisoned on an Outer Plane. The characters might be trying to stop those who seek to release it, or they might want to release it to help defend the world from a greater threat.

To prove themselves worthy of an even greater quest, the characters are sent to slay a horrible monster, win the favor of a powerful planar being, negotiate peace between two warring planar factions, or retrieve a long-lost item on another plane.
An item of legend is being sold at auction in Sigil, the City of Brass, or some other planar metropolis.

globalPlanarDissonance.description: Celestials who visit the Lower Planes and Fiends who visit the Upper Planes experience significant discomfort if their visits last more than a few hours. After finishing a Long Rest on a plane that is alien to its nature, a Celestial or Fiend makes a DC 10 Constitution saving throw. On a failed save, whenever the creature makes a D20 Test, the creature must subtract 1d4 from the roll. The effect is cumulative with each failed save and ends when the creature finishes a Long Rest on a plane that isn't opposed to its nature.

savingThrow.triggerDescription: After finishing a Long Rest on a plane alien to the creature's nature

onFailure.description: Whenever the creature makes a D20 Test, the creature must subtract 1d4 from the roll. The effect is cumulative with each failed save.
onFailure.cumulativeDescription: Each additional failed save adds another 1d4 subtracted from D20 Tests

savingThrow.repeatSaveTiming: After each Long Rest on the opposed plane
savingThrow.recoveryTrigger: Finishing a Long Rest on a plane that isn't opposed to the creature's nature
recoveryMethods: Finishing a Long Rest on a plane that isn't opposed to the creature's nature

savingThrowProbabilities.formula: P(fail | modifier m) = max(0.05, min(0.95, (DC - 1 - m) / 20))
